G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 29, and related provisions governing custody and parenting plans, as the prior custody and parenting-time orders were issued by this Court and the Children reside in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 29.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 29, and related provisions governing custody and parenting plans, as the prior custody and parenting-time orders were issued by this Court and the Children reside in Massachusetts.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Since the entry of the 2020 Order, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances as that term is used in Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the caselaw interpreting it, such as *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/custody case interpreting G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulating the “real advantage” standard and best‑interests analysis for a custodial parent’s relocation. It does not address or apply the “substantial and material change in circumstances” standard under G.L. c. 208, § 28 for modification of an existing order or judgment. Citing Yannas as authority for what constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances under § 28 is therefore not accurate, even though later modification cases sometimes involve relocations of the type discussed in Yannas.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)…”}

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Since the entry of the 2020 Order, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances as that term is used in Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the caselaw interpreting it, such as *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the Massachusetts standard for modifying a prior custody order based on a “substantial and material change in circumstances” under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related caselaw. Smith v. McDonald, as reflected in this concurring opinion, addresses relocation in the context of the paternity statute, G.L. c. 209C, and the rights of an unmarried, sole legal parent prior to adjudication of paternity; it does not analyze or apply the § 28 ‘material change in circumstances’ standard. While it discusses Yannas and removal concepts, it does so to distinguish them, not to articulate or apply the modification standard the proposition references.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “This is not a removal case, and Yannas is inapposite. Neither the judge nor the parties has cited to a single case, from any jurisdiction (and I am not aware of any from my own investigation), that gives a judge authority to pull a parent and child unwillingly back to a State where the parent had a prior and unilateral right to leave. The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Since the entry of the 2020 Order, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances as that term is used in Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the caselaw interpreting it, such as *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns what constitutes a “substantial and material change in circumstances” under Massachusetts law in the context of custody/relocation. Mason v. Coleman directly discusses relocation in joint physical custody situations and, critically, quotes and relies on the ALI Principles stating that a relocation that significantly impairs a parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities constitutes a “substantial change in circumstances.” Thus, Mason is proper authority for using relocation-related changes as a qualifying substantial/material change under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related caselaw.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances … only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]…’
… (4)(c) ‘If neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility…the court should modify the plan…in accordance with the child’s best interests, taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.’”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Since the entry of the 2020 Order, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances as that term is used in Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the caselaw interpreting it, such as *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: Bouchard addresses the criteria and findings required for an initial custody determination, emphasizing that the best interests and welfare of the child are the governing considerations. It does not discuss the standard for *modifying* an existing custody order or define what constitutes a “substantial and material change in circumstances” under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about a material change in circumstances since a prior order.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Children are now older (approximately 8 and 6 years old) than they were at the time of the 2020 Order, and their needs with respect to school routines, sleep, and emotional stability have evolved accordingly, further reinforcing the need to reassess and modify the existing parenting-time schedule in light of current circumstances. See *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) (child’s maturation and changing needs can constitute material change).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss what qualifies as a “material and substantial change in circumstances” for modifying custody, but it does not identify a child’s maturation or changing developmental needs over time as such a change. Instead, the court finds there was no qualifying material change and reverses a custody modification. The only mention of post‑judgment changes concerns work schedules, living arrangements, and relocation—nothing about the child simply growing older as a basis for modification—so it does not support the specific proposition cited.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Taken together, the Defendant’s changed work schedule, his inability to be physically present and awake for many of his ordered overnights, and his reliance on a third party of limited familiarity to the Plaintiff and the Children constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the 2020 Order, within the meaning of Massachusetts law. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns what constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances for modification of an existing custody order, based on a parent’s changed work schedule and caregiving arrangements. Custody of Vaughn does not address modification standards or material change in circumstances at all; it deals with an appeal from an initial custody judgment and focuses on the need for explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its impact on the child. It therefore does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about work schedules, third‑party caregiving, or material change since a prior order.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Taken together, the Defendant’s changed work schedule, his inability to be physically present and awake for many of his ordered overnights, and his reliance on a third party of limited familiarity to the Plaintiff and the Children constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the 2020 Order, within the meaning of Massachusetts law. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns what constitutes a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ for modification of an existing custody order, especially as to a parent’s work schedule, inability to be present for overnights, and reliance on third parties. Custody of Kali expressly does not apply the ‘substantial change in circumstances’/modification standard; it addresses an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) and the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, and it even declines to consider the modification framework under § 20. Accordingly, it provides no authority for what constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances under Massachusetts law and does not support the cited proposition.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: Taken together, the Defendant’s changed work schedule, his inability to be physically present and awake for many of his ordered overnights, and his reliance on a third party of limited familiarity to the Plaintiff and the Children constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the 2020 Order, within the meaning of Massachusetts law. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015).
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: Murray v. Super is a removal and child-support modification case. It does not address whether changes in a parent’s work schedule, inability to be physically present/awake during overnights, or reliance on a third party caregiver constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances. The opinion’s modification discussion concerns the custodial mother’s remarriage and financial contributions from a new spouse, not parenting-time logistics or overnight care arrangements. Thus, citing Murray for that specific material-change proposition misstates its holding and scope.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “In support of his complaint for modification, the father alleged as a material and substantial change of circumstances the mother’s remarriage… The judge further found, however, that the mother now receives estimated contributions from her new husband in the amount of $1,000 per week. Based on those changes, including adding the new husband’s voluntary contributions to the mother’s income into the child support calculation, the judge reduced the father’s child support obligation…”

*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232, 233\u.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in custody and parenting-time matters is the best interests of the child.
*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232, 233\u.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames custody/visitation determinations in terms of promoting the child’s best interests, and describes that goal as the “dominating” one, citing both Massachusetts authority and G.L. c. 208, § 31. Although the case involves religious-upbringing disputes in the context of visitation, the court’s reasoning makes clear that parental liberties may be limited when necessary to serve the child’s best interests, confirming that this is the paramount consideration in such matters under Massachusetts law.
*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232, 233\u.relevant_excerpt: “But the ‘best interests’ of the child are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds, the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents. … If the dominating goal of the enterprise is to serve a child’s best interests, as the cases asseverate (see Vilakazi v. Maxie, supra at 409; cf. G. L. c. 208, § 31 [as to awards of custody])…”

*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in custody and parenting-time matters is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the governing standard in custody-related state interventions as the child’s welfare and best interests, stating that parental rights must yield to the child’s welfare and that the critical question is whether parents are fit to further the child’s welfare and best interests. Although the case is in the specific context of care-and-protection/guardianship and focuses heavily on the parental-unfitness requirement, it clearly recognizes that the child’s welfare/best interests are the paramount consideration against which custody decisions are measured.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.relevant_excerpt: “However, the parents’ right to custody is not absolute, and it must yield to the welfare of the child. … ‘[T]he unfitness standard must be applied whenever the State seeks to terminate parents’ rights to the custody of their minor children….’ … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’ … ‘As parens patriae the State does not act to punish misbehaving parents; rather it acts to protect endangered children.’”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (.proposition: Stability, safety, consistent routines, and adequate supervision during overnight hours are critical components of the Children’s best interests, particularly during school years. *See Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843–44 (courts consider stability of environment and caretaker availability); *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (1998).
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss that Hugo needs a “consistent and predictable” environment and that stability is important in a young child’s life, but it does not specifically address stability, safety, consistent routines, or supervision during *overnight hours* or during *school years* as distinct, critical components of the best‑interests analysis. Its focus is on weighing long‑term developmental advantages of two adoption plans and the general importance of stability and support for his special needs. Thus, while tangentially related to stability, it does not clearly establish the proposition as stated.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that Hugo needs a ‘consistent and predictable’ environment. … Stability in the life of a child, especially one as young as Hugo, is important, as the judge himself recognized. Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 617 (1986). Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in custody and parenting-time matters is the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 208, § 31 (defining legal and physical custody), G.L. c. 209C, § 10 (where applicable to custody and visitation), and the Court’s continuing jurisdiction, the Plaintiff seeks modification of the 2020 Order to conform to the current circumstances and the Children’s best interests.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 208, § 31 (defining legal and physical custody), G.L. c. 209C, § 10 (where applicable to custody and visitation), and the Court’s continuing jurisdiction, the Plaintiff seeks modification of the 2020 Order to conform to the current circumstances and the Children’s best interests.
